title: Councillor says Liverpool’s rat problem could be solved by shooting them all
text:
Cllr Steve Radford suggested testing out ‘a good professional system’

Rats taking over the streets of Liverpool should be wiped out by trained marksmen, one of the city’s councillors has suggested.

Steve Radford, leader of the city’s Liberal Party, voiced the unconventional idea during a discussion about the wider use of guns to shoot animals.

He agreed with the rest of the members that recreational hunting was ‘barbaric’, but added that he would be ‘happy’ to trial a scheme using pest controllers professionally trained in the use of firearms.

City Mayor Joe Anderson said the idea was ‘silly and absurd’, adding that shooting vermin was ‘dismissed many years ago’, the BBC reported.

Labour cabinet member Cllr Paul Brant also parodied the suggestion, tweeting: ‘I can’t think of anything that could possibly make this a tricky idea. The comforting and relaxing sound of firearm discharges in residential streets; the fun of dodging ricocheting bullets; the acceptable collateral damage of the odd pet.’

Cllr Radford, representative for the Tuebrook and Stoneycroft ward, said the council had forked out £1.5million to repair walls that had been gnawed through by rats.

‘We have an overwhelming outbreak of vermin in Liverpool,’ he added.

‘Alleyways are collapsing where rats are burrowing underneath them.’

He suggested implementing a ‘good professional system’ inviting shooting club members to ‘come at set times to cull the rats’.

‘Maybe its worth looking at an isolated trial and asking the shooting lobby if we could look at a scheme using people who are trained in the use of guns to go out and kill rats and see if it has a benefit to the public,’ he told the Liverpool Echo.

‘I would be happy for us to try it in my ward first.’

Mr Anderson rubbished the idea, telling the meeting it ‘doesn’t deserve any credibility at all’.

He said ‘the most effective and most cost effective’ way of curbing the problem was cutting down on the amount of food waste on the streets and targeted poisoning programmes.
